head.citation-title: Analysis of biomass gasification and PEMFC integrated systems for power generation: A combined heat and power approach
head.abstracts: The performance and the feasibility of an alternative combined heat and power system based on biomass gasification and proton exchange membrane fuel cell (PEMFC) processes was studied for residential applications satisfying thermal and electrical demands. A model of the integrated CHP system was employed to analyze its performance under different operating conditions. The system was designed for the electrical load of 5 kw. Simulation results showed that the gasification process could produce the synthesis gas having the hydrogen content of ∼ 25-35 mole % and the high heating value of 4-10 MJ/N-cu m. A purification process consisting of a water gas shift reactor and a preferential oxidation reactor is also necessary to reduce the concentration of CO in the synthesis gas to be < 10 ppm for PEMFC. The useful heat in the high-temperature synthesis gas derived from the gasifer was recovered and used in the purification step and thus the efficiency of the fuel processor was enhanced. Effect of a load level on the performance of PEMFC was studied. The results of the system evaluation indicated that the total efficiency of the PEMFC-based cogeneration system was 92% and the electrical efficiency was 22%. This is an abstract of a paper presented at the CHISA 2012 - 20th International Congress of Chemical and Process Engineering and PRES 2012 - 15th Conference on Process Integration, Modelling and Optimisation for Energy Saving and Pollution Reduction (Prague, Czech Republic 8/25-29/2012).
